items.title: Dark mode might be burning more juice than you think
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Most people crank up the brightness, making energy savings moot

Using apps and websites in dark mode can actually use more energy than standard mode, according to researchers, as it causes people to crank up the brightness.…

items.title: DXC paid 50% more than original contract value for disastrous public sector Oracle project
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Systems integrator secured 'variation' just before mega SAP migration put on hold

Systems integrator DXC accrued over 50 percent more than its original contract value for completing less than half the scheduled contract term during a disastrous project to move a UK government body off an ageing SAP ERP system and onto Oracle Fusion.…

items.title: Ghost ransomware crew continues to haunt IT depts with scarily bad infosec
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
FBI and CISA issue reminder - deep sigh - about the importance of patching and backups

The operators of Ghost ransomware continue to claim victims and score payments, but keeping the crooks at bay is possible by patching known vulnerabilities and some basic infosec actions, according to a joint advisory issued Wednesday by the FBI and US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency.…

items.title: Medusa ransomware gang demands $2M from UK private health services provider
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
2.3 TB held to ransom as biz formerly known as Virgin Care tells us it's probing IT 'security incident'

Exclusive  HCRG Care Group, a private health and social services provider, has seemingly fallen victim to the Medusa ransomware gang, which is threatening to leak what's claimed to be stolen internal records unless a substantial ransom is paid.…

items.title: A big AI build has ‘stalled’ and won’t happen this year as funds and GPUs prove elusive
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Arista trumpeted its role in this project for a year. Good thing business is otherwise solid

Big Tech’s plans to spend hundreds of billions on infrastructure during 2025 are often considered to demonstrate near-endless demand for artificial intelligence, but networking vendor Arista has just revealed a large AI build has “stalled” due to lack of funds and hardware.…

items.title: France tops China’s tokamak record with 22-minute plasma containment run
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Nice number, but also not much more than a nice advance

France’s Commissariat à L'énergie Atomique et aux Energies Alternatives on Tuesday claimed it’s topped China’s recently-established for record maintaining fusion plasma in a tokamak, and therefore taken another step towards building a fusion reactor capable of producing cheap energy.…

items.title: US Army soldier linked to Snowflake extortion rampage admits breaking the law
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
That's the way the cookie melts

A US Army soldier suspected of hacking AT&T and Verizon has admitted leaking online people's private call records.…

items.title: Trump can't quickly or easily kill the CHIPS Act, but he can fire the workers funded by it
items.author: Tobias Mann
items.summary:
Reported layoffs suggest R&D functions may be hobbled, fab subsidies also at risk

Comment  US President Donald Trump has made it plain he’s not a fan of the $53 billion CHIPS and Science Act that funds semiconductor manufacturing and research on American soil – and now it appears he’s decided to make substantial staff cuts at the agencies that administer it.…

items.title: Trump’s DoD CISO pick previously faced security clearance suspension
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Hey, at least Katie Arrington brings a solid resume

Donald Trump's nominee for a critical DoD cybersecurity role sports a resume that outshines many of his past picks, despite previously suspended security clearance.…

items.title: Microsoft shows off novel quantum chip that can scale to 'a million qubits'. So far: Eight
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
Not just a matter of time but a matter of Majorana fermions, too

Microsoft says it has developed a quantum-computing chip made with novel materials that is expected to enable the development of quantum computers for meaningful, real-world applications within – you guessed it – years rather than decades.…

items.title: Check out this free automated tool that hunts for exposed AWS secrets in public repos
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
You can find out if your GitHub codebase is leaking keys ... but so can miscreants

A free automated tool that lets anyone scan public GitHub repositories for exposed AWS credentials has been released.…

items.title: We meet the protesters who want to ban Artificial General Intelligence before it even exists
items.author: Thomas Claburn
items.summary:
STOP AI warns of doomsday scenario, demands governments pull the plug on advanced models

Feature  On Saturday at the Silverstone Cafe in San Francisco, a smattering of activists gathered to discuss plans to stop the further advancement of artificial intelligence.…

items.title: Want to play billionaire for a day? This app lets you rent your own armed goon squad
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Black Escalade motorcade sold separately - of course

Need to turn heads and burn cash while out on the town? A new app lets you hire armed bodyguards to escort you around - chauffeur included - provided you're in Los Angeles or New York City.…

items.title: KDE Plasma 6.3 released – and 6.3.1 is already here
items.author: Liam Proven
items.summary:
A year on from the big overhaul of Plasma 6, more functionality appears

KDE Plasma 6.3 is here, closely followed by a point release, alongside new versions of the KDE Frameworks and KDE Gear apps collection.…

items.title: Microsoft boffins promise entire game worlds made from AI slop
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
WHAM, bam, no thank you, ma'am?

Eggheads at Microsoft have produced a generative AI tool they say can create a three-dimensional game world to help developers design and tweak gameplay.…

items.title: Telco to open lab to test cell network interoperability with satellites
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Because 4G notspots aren't much good to anyone

Vodafone and AST SpaceMobile plan to open a research hub this summer to test and validate the integration of orbital services with terrestrial cellphone networks.…

items.title: Your days of driver sync via Windows Server Update Services are numbered
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Microsoft suggests a move to the cloud

Microsoft has issued administrators a 60-day warning – driver synchronization using Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) will be deprecated.…

items.title: Odds of city-killer asteroid 2024 YR4 hitting Earth creep upward
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
It's probably fine

As the risk corridor narrows for asteroid 2024 YR4, the possibility of a collision with Earth in 2032 have increased.…

items.title: Hundreds of Dutch medical records bought for pocket change at flea market
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
15GB of sensitive files traced back to former software biz

Typically shoppers can expect to find tie-dye t-shirts, broken lamps and old disco records at flea markets, now it seems storage drives filled with huge volumes of sensitive data can be added to that list.…

items.title: Mobile operators brace for bigger, faster headaches with 6G
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
NGMN reports what telcos want, but admits most can be delivered by 5G

Mobile operators are pushing for consensus on the key components of next-gen 6G networks, warning that a new radio interface could add complexity – though they acknowledge it would also allow for higher data rates.…

items.title: Type-safe C-killer Delphi hits 30, but a replacement has risen
items.author: Liam Proven
items.summary:
The FOSS world has replicated most of it in Lazarus

Delphi is still very much with us, but the FOSS world also has its own, largely compatible, GUI-based Object Pascal environment – and it's worth a look.…

items.title: Microsoft declutters Windows 11 File Explorer in the name of Euro privacy
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Also hammers another nail into Cortana's coffin with the end of Location History

Microsoft had a Valentine's Day gift for Windows Insiders, firing another arrow into the heart of Cortana while also attempting to soothe European privacy concerns.…

items.title: London celebrity talent agency reports itself to ICO following Rhysida attack claims
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Showbiz members' passport scans already plastered online

A London talent agency has reported itself to the UK's data protection watchdog after the Rhysida ransomware crew last week claimed it had attacked the business, which represents luminaries of stage and screen.…

items.title: HP Inc to build future products atop grave of flopped 'AI pin'
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Tech and people behind IoT brooch that reviewers instantly hated will one day pep up printers

The “AI Pin” produced by company called Humane was a leading tender for 2024’s biggest consumer tech flop, but that hasn’t stopped HP acquiring some of the code and people behind the device and using it as the basis for a new innovation team that will infuse its printers and conference room kit with AI.…

items.title: Einstein Probe finds two stars that have spent 40 million years taking turns eating each other
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
Odd X-ray flashes gave the game away, just few weeks after China-led mission launched

The Einstein Probe space telescope has spotted evidence of one star consuming matter from another.…

items.title: Trump teases 25% semiconductor tariffs that will go ‘substantially higher’
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Envisions phased introduction dependent on manufacturing commitments

United States President Donald Trump has hinted at substantial tariffs on imported semiconductors.…

items.title: Healthcare outfit that served military personnel settles allegations it faked infosec compliance for $11M
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
If this makes you feel sick, knowing this happened before ransomware actors started targeting medical info may help

An alleged security SNAFU that occurred during the Obama administration has finally been settled under the second Trump administration.…

items.title: Palo Alto firewalls under attack as miscreants chain flaws for root access
items.author: Iain Thomson
items.summary:
If you want to avoid urgent patches, stop exposing management consoles to the public internet

A flaw patched last week by Palo Alto Networks is now under active attack and, when chained with two older vulnerabilities, allows attackers to gain root access to affected systems.…

items.title: Acer signals 10% laptop price hike in US, blames Trump's extra China tariff
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
Analyst tells El Reg to expect more of this across hardware brands

Acer has become one of the first major computer makers to confirm it will hike laptop prices in the US, citing fresh import tariffs on Chinese-made hardware imposed by the Trump administration.…

items.title: Snake Keylogger slithers into Windows, evades detection with AutoIt-compiled payload
items.author: Jessica Lyons
items.summary:
Because stealing your credentials, banking info, and IP just wasn’t enough

A new variant of Snake Keylogger is making the rounds, primarily hitting Windows users across Asia and Europe. This strain also uses the BASIC-like scripting language AutoIt to deploy itself, adding an extra layer of obfuscation to help it slip past detection.…

items.title: Looks like paywalls are coming soon to a subreddit near you
items.author: Brandon Vigliarolo
items.summary:
What do Redditors think? Well, it wouldn't be Reddit if they were happy

Redditors love a topic to gripe about, and this week the focus will likely be on CEO Steve Huffman's claim that paywalled content is coming to the so-called Front Page of the Internet.…

items.title: GNOME 48 beta is another nail in X11's coffin
items.author: Liam Proven
items.summary:
Our first look at the default desktop for Fedora 42 and Ubuntu 'Plucky Puffin'

The next version of the default desktop for most of the big Linux distros is in beta. Here's what to expect next month, or soon thereafter.…

items.title: US newspaper publisher uses linguistic gymnastics to avoid saying its outage was due to ransomware
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Called it an 'incident' in SEC filing, but encrypted apps and data exfiltration suggest Lee just can’t say the R word

US newspaper publisher Lee Enterprises is blaming its recent service disruptions on a "cybersecurity attack," per a regulatory filing, and is the latest company to avoid using the dreaded R word.…

items.title: City-slaying space rock 2024 YR4 still has 2.4% shot at smacking Earth
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Scientists refine estimates, but can't yet rule out an impact

The latest figures from the European Space Agency (ESA) on the trajectory of asteroid 2024 YR4 show a reduction in uncertainty around the object's orbit while the probability of impact remains low.…

items.title: FreSSH bugs undiscovered for years threaten OpenSSH security
items.author: Connor Jones
items.summary:
Exploit code now available for MitM and DoS attacks

Researchers can disclose two brand-new vulnerabilities in OpenSSH now that patches have been released.…

items.title: Oracle extends 19c database support to 2032, making it 'longest strategic release'
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Meanwhile, on-prem version of 23ai remains uncertain

Oracle has postponed the end of support date for its popular 19c database as users await news of a mainstream on-prem version of its latest database, 23ai.…

items.title: Time to make C the COBOL of this century
items.author: Rupert Goodwins
items.summary:
Lions juggling chainsaws are fun to watch, but you wouldn't want them trimming your trees

Opinion  Nobody likes The Man. When a traffic cop tells you to straighten up and slow down or else, profound thanks are rarely the first words on your lips. Then you drive past a car embedded in a tree, surrounded by blue lights and cutting equipment. Perhaps Officer Dibble had a point.…

items.title: Grok 3 wades into the AI wars with 'beta' rollout
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Musk's latest attempt at a 'maximally truth-seeking' bot arrives

Grok 3 has begun rolling out. xAI founder Elon Musk describes the chatbot as "a maximally truth-seeking AI, even if that truth is sometimes at odds with what is politically correct."…

items.title: Huawei to bring massively expensive trifold smartphone to world market
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
There's everything to play for, but there ain't no Play Store

Huawei is bringing its triple-fold Mate XT smartphone to a global audience, but with an eye-watering reported price tag, the question is – who will want to buy it?…

items.title: Kelsey Hightower on dodging AI and the need for a glossary of IT terms
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
The science of the appliance and opening the lid of the black box to find... it's just software

Interview  The tech industry has a habit of reinventing itself every few years. Kelsey Hightower would like someone to come up with a glossary because software is software, no matter what it gets called.…

items.title: UK electrical utility seeks partner for £81M SAP overhaul as support deadline closes in
items.author: Lindsay Clark
items.summary:
Integrations with third-party software await chosen provider

A UK electrical infrastructure biz is seeking a systems integrator to help it migrate from a 25-year-old SAP ERP system to the latest S/4HANA platform in a contract set to be worth almost a quarter of its annual turnover.…

items.title: Lloyds Bank reviews tech and engineering personnel in reorg
items.author: Paul Kunert
items.summary:
Admits it will be saying 'goodbye to talented people' in UK amid fears of jobs being offshored to India

Lloyds Banking Group this month launched a review of the technology and engineering professionals working in the UK operation with headcount reductions inevitable and some roles being offshored to Lloyds Technology Center in India.…

items.title: Avaya hangs up on users with fewer than 200 SaaSy contact center seats
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Customers told to pay up, quit, or wait for promised alternative ‘innovation’ coming real soon now

Avaya has advised customers and resellers of a planned “evolution” of its products that starts with a requirement to license at least 200 seats worth of its SaaS-y contact center wares by June 30, 2025.…

items.title: Indian authorities seize loot from collapsed BitConnect crypto scam
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Devices containing crypto wallets tracked online, then in the real world

Indian authorities seize loot from BitConnect crypto-Ponzi scheme Devices containing crypto wallets tracked online, then in the real world India’s Directorate of Enforcement has found and seized over $200 million of loot it says are the proceeds of the BitConnect crypto-fraud scheme.…

items.title: DeepSeek disappears from South Korean app stores over privacy concerns
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Nation also orders thousands of GPUs to advance local AI smarts

South Korea suspends DeepSeek, which vows to return in better shape Nation also orders enough GPUs to train many more LLMs South Korea’s Personal Information Protection Commission has suspended local availability of apps from Chinese LLM-and-chatbot developer DeepSeek.…

items.title: Even Linus Torvalds can have trouble with autocycle … autocracy… AUTOCOMPLETE!
items.author: Simon Sharwood
items.summary:
Penguin Emperor's weekly State Of The Kernel post went astray

Next time autocomplete takes over and you accidentally send an email to the wrong person or group, perhaps it will be a little solace to know that one of the world’s most accomplished technologists – Linux kernel boss Linus Torvalds – just made that same mistake.…

items.title: The future of AI is ... analog? Upstart bags $100M to push GPU-like brains on less juice
items.author: Tobias Mann
items.summary:
EnCharge claims 150 TOPS/watt, a 20x performance-per-watt edge

Interview  AI chip startup EnCharge claims its analog artificial intelligence accelerators could rival desktop GPUs while using just a fraction of the power. Impressive — on paper, at least. Now comes the hard part: Proving it in the real world.…

items.title: Why did the Windows 95 setup use Windows 3.1?
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
If MS-DOS could play Doom, surely a battleship gray button was a possibility?

Veteran Microsoft engineer Raymond Chen has responded to suggestions that the Windows 95 setup was overly complicated. People wanted to know: Why not just do that whole thing in MS-DOS?…

items.title: NAND flash prices plunge amid supply glut, factory output cut
items.author: Dan Robinson
items.summary:
Flaky demand for PCs and smartphones blamed

NAND flash prices are expected to slide due to oversupply, forcing memory chipmakers to cut production to match lower-than-expected orders from PC and smartphone manufacturers.…

items.title: There's a slight chance Asteroid 2024 YR4 could hit Moon in 2032
items.author: Richard Speed
items.summary:
Very unlikely, but could make for a neat light show if it does

There is a chance, albeit slim, that asteroid 2024 YR4 could hit the Moon, creating a new crater and an explosion that might just be visible from Earth.…
